comment: Nose is not sweet. Rye flavor. Medium spice finish. Bitter.
Not bad, but not great. Needs rocks to evenly pallet and then just sips can’t take to much of it at once
Herbal flavor on the palate. Almost a grassy taste. You can taste the rye but it’s not over the top. Very different from the bourbons I am used to.

Wow, much better than I was expecting at its price point. On the nose you get a bit of a smoky smell with a faint citrus smell. The taste has a very nice spice to it along with some vanilla and cinnamon that lingers, and a creaminess that took me by surprise for a rye. Great value.
A reliable rye to keep in the cabinet. Great with a splash of water or in your preferred rye cocktail.

Neat; Spicey & sweet nose. Spicey flavor with notes of oak & pepper. Light sweet finish. Mild spicey lingering flavor.
With two dashes of Angostra bitters; Becomes more spicey overall. Usually the sweet herbal flavor over rides most whiskey's but this seems to stand up to it nicely. 4/5 stars.
Had in "The Widow's Sting" cocktail; rye whiskey, Grand Marnier, Amaro & orange oil.
Has a sweet herbal nose. Sweet  herbal and floral flavor & finish. 4/5 stars.
$24.99 750ml Total Wine Dallas, TX
My "house" rye - my go-to, mixing rye. I enjoy it neat also.

When I first tasted this bourban I was like this is good, def a 4. But three longer I drank the wheels started falling off a bit. I liked the spicy rye but then it became slightly so so, bit rough and the thing that did it for me was it just became to sweet. Still its only $40USD here which is cheap 3.5 I'll give it.
Still the best affordable mixing rye on the market. Not the kindest neat sipper, but it makes a beast of a Manhattan.
ooohh nose: Candylicious palate: sweet and spicy just like naughty and nice finish: malted barley def shines through, bit of a turn off, otherwise a winner.
pretty nice rye. spicy. not very rich  though. does not linger long, either. but not cloyingly sweet, either.

Mashbill: 51% Rye, 37% Corn, 12% Malted Barley

Price: My friend brought this, but it’s $24.99 at the local Total Wine in Houston, Texas

Setting: Neat in a Glencairn, while playing Twilight Struggle with a friend

Color: Copper

Nose: I found the nose pretty faint. I picked up cereal notes and that was about it. I do wonder how long the bottle was open, however, as that may have muted some of the aromas. (16/25 points)

Taste: I loved the taste of this. Peanuts, rye spice, cereal, and cinnamon, with a nice mouthfeel. Packs some heat, but in a pleasing way. (46/50 points)

Finish: Medium duration. Maple syrup, rye spice, and cinnamon. (18/25) points)

Conclusion: I really enjoyed this. It’s not particularly complex, but it has lots of flavor and tastes good. My friend who brought it over claims that it also makes a mean Manhattan, and it’s affordable enough to use as such. I don’t have much rye whiskey experience (I like High West but haven’t tried a whole lot else), but this was quite nice, especially for the price. I’ll have to pick up a bottle.

80/100
an absolute go to when u r stiff...

Color: Light amber
Nose: 3.25 | toasted grain, dried fruit, bananas (think bowl of oatmeal)
Palate: 3.5 | palate follows the nose - lots of dried fruit, bananas, toasted grain, white pepper, slight mint and oak
Finish: 3.5 | fairly long, spicy finish
Price: 4 | $25 or less 
    
Verdict: Bottle
Enjoyed it neat but fantastic in a Manhattan.
3.7. A large bite at the end. Tried with ice and it mellowed

Nose- Black pepper and a light pickle brine. There is a hint of vanilla. 
Body- Spicy on the tip of tongue with a hint of bitterness.
Nose- Bitterness continues. Not bad but fairly non-complex.

High quality for the price, which kicks it from a 4 to a 5. Floral grassy nose, balanced grain and oak body, and a spicy rye finish, all with a 100 proof kick. Great mixer for classic cocktails, or drink it with a little ice.
Sharp but smooth, sweet and good, best rye

The nose is deep and heavy with rye bread, dill pickle juice, and pepper, very acidic and juicy. When freshly opened it has a bandaid medicinal note that dissipates after some air. The palate is spicy and rich, more distinct dill pickle spices as well as Mediterranean herbs like thyme and oregano. The finish stays very herbal but also has a hint of vanilla. Very full bodied.
Too strong to sip.  Absolutely awesome in a Manhattan.
Sweeter than I expected. Normally a bourbon guy. This was good! A little heavy for a daily sipper.  I’ll keep it on the shelf for a change. Worth the money plus !

Aroma: rye (duh), browned butter, buttered toast, homemade caramel, vanilla, Mtn Dew(?)
Palate: vanilla, oak, baking spices aplenty, Mediterranean spices, lemon peel
Great go-to rye. Big, bold, bready flavours upfront. Subtlety isn't its style.
My go to rye for both sipping and cocktails.

For me this is the most middle-of-the-road rye I've ever had. Nothing really negative to say, just about exactly what you'd expect from 50% BIB Rye. It's got some heat. It's got spice. It's got pepper. It's just missing that extra something to push it over the edge. Excellent for standard rye cocktails but I'd go the extra couple bucks for Sazerac Rye 100/100 times.
Butter, vanilla, cinnamon, and slightly musty barrel like damp hay. Nice rye spice and a ton of heat. Buttery middle. Good for some cocktails but not my sipper.
Came recommended by the bartender. I'm impressed. Sweet and smooth for a rye, still flavorful.
Rye spice, cherries, vanilla. Beautifully sweet and drinkable for 100 proof. If you can find this stuff just grab it. For $25 you won’t be disappointed.

Rye is becoming increasingly popular, and I certainly understand why. It's flavorsome, affordable and has a bit more punch than your average bourbon. Rittenhouse from Heaven Hill is an old classic and a good starting point to explore rye. The nose is unmistakably spicy with loads of cinnamon, cloves and caramelized sugar. Gingerbread, sweet oranges and hints of floral add to the complexity. After a strong and gingery arrival, the taste develops aromatic and semidry, with notes of bitter honey, mint and wood spices lingering in the medium finish. A steal!

RATING: 3.9/5.0 stars ≙ 86 pts → FIRST-CLASS [-]

Weaker than expected spice, strong rye aftertaste mild oak, with a mild brown sugar finish, maybe some caramel. Body is surprisingly a little watery, especially for 100 proof.

Pleasant, but not exceptional.

Rittenhouse is my first bottle of rye, so don't have a lot of comparison with others in the category, other than a quick taste of Bulleit Rye once.

Enjoyed neat in Glencairn.  Nose is odd on this one for me.  Sort of a mildly sweet woody burnt sugar mixed with a medicinal smell or hay, maybe pine, cedar, or wintergreen.  On the palate the rye spice immediately jumps on the tongue.  Quite spicy and peppery but it fades fairly quickly, leaving more of that medicinal taste that I got from the nose.  I can't quite place it, but it almost seems like a band-aid or iodine quality. Taste isn't sweet, and more on the tart side.  Also for 50% ABV, it seems fairly tame, like it could be closer to 40%.  Finish is fairly short and settles into toasted wood and honey.  Long in the finish I get a grassy note, maybe hay again.  

Overall, not a bad first entry into ryes for me but the strange medicinal quality just isn't all that appealing as a daily sip.  I've tried Bulleit rye, and it was much smoother and less spicy, which isn't typical of a rye, so I'm not sure it's a great comparison.  Although I probably prefered the Bulleit for its flavor profile.  Maybe the Rittenhouse will grow on me, but not a great first impression.  Cheers!
Bold flavors of spicy rye, caramel, and clove. Very tasty, fun, balanced, and flavorful. I’ve been sipping it neat but it would also shine in a classic cocktail. Also a great value!
sharp. vanilla. corn? SWEET. I can imagine putting sugar in this and just having it for dessert. It’s not super sweet upfront (but somewhat sweet) but then the sweetness lingers.
Exceptional and even better when left in a covered glass to breathe a bit before drinking neat

As someone that owns over 30 different Ryes this is one of the best values on the market.  Fairly easy to get and affordable and a great taste.  Also, a great lazy evening Rye to make an Old Fashion with.  Enjoy.
sample / Just on edge of being overheated with spice, this is a pretty fantastic value.

Nose of oak and peppermint transitions to vanilla and spearmint after a while. First taste is hot ethanol wrapped around a creamy, smooth, full-bodied center. Alcohol dissipates quickly, leaving fresh oak, sweet fruit, slight baby aspirin, mint, and light clove. The finish is long and satisfying, mostly oak and clove.

A little water mutes the flavor too much, leaving mainly cola flavor and a shorter, oak and cola finish.

There is no dill aroma or flavor. Clove is not nearly as pronounced as the 95% ryes from MGP.

This is a complex and satisfying dram. I’m looking forward to finishing the bottle.

Just picked up a bottle of this for the first time in a couple of years. Thought it was a good time to re-review since my earlier review was done when I was fairly new to the brown spirit game. 

Nose: Hay, Leather, Old Oak. Like standing in an old barn or tack room. Keep exploring to pull out notes of Light vanilla and just a hint of dill way in the back. After it sits for a few minutes a custardy note starts to evolve.

Neat in a Glencairn: This one is Oakier than I remember. It enters with the Hay and leather. Just a hint of vanilla/caramel sweetness. Dusty and dry. That great musty oak note that I find in a lot of Heaven Hill presents in the mid-palate. It manages to be oaky without being bitter or tannic. No (or very minimal) dill that a lot of people find off-putting in some of the higher rye mash bills. A pleasant warming sensation paired with a peppery tingle on the finish. The musty oak note coats and lingers along with a little pepper spice. 

Splash: A couple drops of water really enhances both nose and palate. It shoves the rye notes to the back and gives the nose a fall-esque vibe. Butterscotch and nutmeg. It gives it a creamier mouthfeel with the butterscotch, vanilla and nutmeg becoming the predominant notes complimented by the heavy oak. 

Verdict: I guess I just needed a reminder of how much I liked this one. Of the ryes that I have sampled, this is a solid second place behind the High West Double Rye. The High West has a lot of notes that you don't think would pair well together (think an improv jazz session) while the Rittenhouse hits a few well placed complimentary chords (think a meat and potatoes garage band crunching out an AC/DC cover tune). Both are equally enjoyable depending on your mood.
Very smooth rye goes down easy with great flavor

It's like drinking campfire marshmallows dipped in a sugary butter. It's soft on the nose, with a sugar/spice mix, but bites hard with some heat on first sip. Texture is buttery smooth, with a very sugary finish. Tastes like cake, butter cream frosting and marshmallows, and it lingers in a good way.

Of note, unlike other bourbons and ryes in my experience, this one tastes better neat. Dilution seemed to take away some of the impact of the flavor profile for me.
Delicious, butter, maple syrup, brown sugar. Amazing for the price.
Very good, just not my cup of tea.
spicy taste, and due to its high ABV might water it with a few drops in order to experience at its richest form
Really strong for cocktails, light spice and smoke bites
Great clean rye flavor. Smooth especially for its proof. Could use more depth of flavor.
A great classic rye, excellent in cocktails and really stands out in a Manhattan or Old Fashioned.  Price can’t be beat for the quality, a must have for bars.

Crème brulée, a slight hint of smoke, something savory and a bit of tart cherry. Spice, heat and a dusty lingering finish with cinnamon, mint and a faint hint of cocoa. Great value rye. Our go to for Manhattans and a good sipper too.
Nice honey/vanilla nose. Strong bite, but strangely smooth beneath that. This is really not a sipping whiskey, though this rating is for sipping. That said, this is my favorite mixing whiskey.

Go-to for Manhattans due to price and proof.  The older and pricier Pikesville may be a worthy successor for me, though this sub-$20 bottle is really incredible.

Smoke; honey; mild iodine; clove; cherry and vanilla.

Grabbed a bottle of Rittenhouse, one of my go to bottles, and first rye I ever had. 

Look: the label is red, so the spirit looks especially dark in the bottle, but in the glass comes out a more light brown, slightly golden. The rye sticks to the glass once moved around my Glencairn, with alcohol legs dissipating pretty quickly. 

Nose: I get a lot of butterscotch, cinnamon, clove, really a bunch of spice, with that butterscotch sweetness. Slight nuttiness

Palate: my first taste was like eating potpourri: cinnamon all over the place, but not in a super spicy note but almost a cinnamon granola bar. Wonderful.  The second sip brings the sweet butterscotch notes more, sugars, and clove cinnamon. 

Finish: Almost no bitterness at all, and a medium amount of heat.  The taste that lingers most would be the cinnamon that dominates the whole dram, with some earthy notes hitting a minute or so in. 

Overall: While I’ve had Rittenhouse a number of times, I never really had much of an ability to pick apart flavors, but finally having this with a little more experience, I love it. The cinnamon is beautiful, with little cloying bitterness in the finish makes this about perfect for me. I’m excited to try the big brother, Pikesville, in the near future.
reminds me of Savannah sazeracs drinks
my favorite rye for old fashioned's. High proof is perfect with the simple syrup and bitters
Dry charcoal but nice to sip over ice. had at Avery in Boston.
For the price this is amazing.
The perfect old fashioned rye...good on it's own but best to make the perfect old fashioned
Excellent, accessible, balanced and at an extremely reasonable price. Enough complexity to keep you yearning for it. Love the balance of fruit and rye spice. Preferring neat.
A smooth rye taste that finishes with a tasty syrup flavor and mouth feel. Slight burn.
This was perfect for a homemade whiskey sour made with freshly squeezed lemon juice.
Great taste!  Lingers on the tongue and begs you for more.  My go to Rye.

Smells of browned, well, brown sugar; a buttery molasses. Incredible cinnamon flavor, more powerful than any other rye. Almost a fresh cut grass or herb taste on the forefront. Finishes smooth like a Tennessee whiskey.

Nose is dried fruit and grain almost resembled cereal. Nice dash of spice on the front then a nice lighter mouthful of  slightly sweet and a delicious fruity end. A beautifully balanced rye whiskey that finishes a bit quicker than most but has you craving more. A great affordable high rye bottled in bond at 100 proof. Buy yourself a bottle today, I promise you will not be disappointed to keep this little hidden gem in your bar for when company is over.

"0-1.5: Disgusting. Worth only mixing or meeting the drain. 
2: Bad. Wouldn’t feel bad mixing
2.5: Sub-par. OK, but bland or somewhat flawed. 
3: Good. Decent stuff, but not a top re-buy
3.5: Very good. I’d love to keep a bottle around
4: Excellent. A go to for me that is worthy of celebrating - will never get old
4.5: Incredible
5:Perfect and an all time favorite
good but a little alcohol forward on the finish for me
Great in a Manhattan with Dolin sweet vermouth
First real taste of a rye, it had a nice flavor and aroma.
smooth for the proof. affordable and really good. good spiced flavor. slight sweetness. really good

My go to for Old Fashioneds.

I'm not experienced in tasting and distinguishing flavors. I get a lot of spice but in a smooth way. First few times I tried it I thought I could taste cocoa but not much anymore.

I'm a fan and will keep it in my bar, as long as I can find it.
Nice rye. It is on the spicy side but overall for under $30. A good quality rye.

Neat.  Nose is typical rye.  Hints of honey.  Smooth mouth feel with sugar on the palate.  Rye spice rushes through on the taste, but subsided to a blend of honey, cinnamon, and vanilla.  Fantastic rye.
Spicy tasty Rye. Excellent value for the price point
Spectacular rye for mixing. Makes wonderful Manhattans and Whisky Sours.
spice - good in an old fashioned

Bang for your buck! This bargain rye is bursting with flavor. On the nose, sweet milk chocolate, cheesecake and oak. On the palate, a manageable forward kick of spice, baked sugar cookies, cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla icing with a rich oily texture
A little too spicy for me at first. Tasted apple pretty quick. Not boring that’s for sure.
Spicy, an unfortunate jet fuel finish
Nose of lime. Spicy. Brown sugar
Smoother and sweeter with less spice and more fruit than I expected from a bonded rye, probably due to the barely rye/high corn mashbill.
Caramel and vanilla in the nose, strong rye spice and more caramel on the palate
Burn on tongue right away. Hint of caramel and oak. Oily texture. Finish is syrupy
Fruity. Better than I was expecting.
Fruit. Strong alcohol. Light burnt taste. Strong grain

Nose... Sweet and spicy rye seed. Hints of cocoa, cherry and marshmallow...

Appearance... Dark amber meets light copper...

Taste... Big flavors.. Cinnamon, Rye, smooth desert qualities, nutty and rich.

Overall... Great to superb at this price point. The flavors are so refined yet rich and bold. The immediate mouth full has such sweetness which is followed by earthy spicy notes. Just such a fantastic rye whisky served neat and will always be in my rye arsenal, ESPECIALLY at this rediculously low price point...
Spicy. Makes a long lasting old fashioned- one that lingers and stays with you.
Go to for Manhattans and Old Fashions.
Earthy. Oak and rye. Very dry.
Caramel and marshmallow on the nose with the slightest bit of raw potato. Cool at first then quick-building spiciness. Anise and buttered-brown sugar. A bit of hay and grass.

The nose takes a minute to open up, but once it does you get a pleasant camp fire with roasted marshmallows, rye spices, cinnamon and a touch of brown butter. The palate is dry and rich with strong baking spices up front along with equally strong rye spices, with brown butter, oak and hints of mint, caramel and brown sugar. The finish is medium long with fading rye and baking spices, with brown butter, brown sugar and oak softly in the background.
Flawless whiskey, perfect for a wide range of whiskey-based cocktails. The best of such cocktails is the Black Manhattan. This is also a pleasant sipping whiskey, especially on ice.
Strong. Has a musky flavor like a super tangent fruit
Entry oozes butter cream, dark caramel, and brown sugar; midpalate focuses more on the grain as the flavor becomes toasty, fruity and honeyed. Ends honey sweet, decadent and maple-like.

It’s certainly a decent buy. Oily might be an understatement. It sticks around for a long time. 

"0-1: Beyond bad. Complete waste of money according to my tastebuds. 
2: Bad. Simply not my taste
2.5: Sub-par. Ill drink it... but only because its whiskey.
3: Good. Decent stuff, but not a rebuy
3.5: Very good. I might buy again
4: Excellent: Will be purchasing a bottle asap
4.5: Incredible: top of the purchase list
5:Amazing: cost and taste are worth every cent"
Feels like Bourbon mixed up with a bit of smoky Scotch.

One of my personal favorite rye whiskies, full bodied and spicy but not overly hot. This rye can hold its own in a cocktail, neat, or with a big cube. Nice vanilla oaky nose, I get a lot of burnt marshmallow sweetness, some nutty and oak roundness fill the body with light maple lingering. Really nice spicy sweet finish hangs around to remind you why you came here in the first place.
Spicy, cheap rye that is good for mixing but wouldn’t recommend sipping

Bottle pour at home, neat in a Glencairn.  Second tasting after first trying a few days ago.  Nose is hot and spicy.  Definite rye bite.  Some grassy notes, strong pepper spice is nearly overwhelming the woody notes, hints of caramel and tobacco.  This is a solid rye, but is a perfect example of why I prefer a wheater.  Just not smooth at all, and the rye spice overwhelms.  5/25/19
One of the best Rye's I've ever had and a great price point too.

Sweet rye and cinnamon on the nose, spicy vanilla and cinnamon on the palate, long spicy finish. A splash of water opened up vanilla on the nose, rye sweetness on the palate, and tamed the finish a little.
Very smooth! Smell of fruit and a smooth finish. Can tell 100 proof but not overly hot. Very well done. Would buy again.
Very smooth! Smell of fruit and a smooth finish. Can tell 100 proof but not overly hot. Very well done. Would buy again.
Pretty good rye. On par with James Pepper and a notch below Knob Creek. Not as buttery, definitely runs hot. I like this rye, but I don’t love it.
good daily driver for the price. very happy with it
i think that its over rated. it tastes great mixed.
Decent juice. Glad I tried it. Would not get it again though.

niet mijn ding. ruikt heel lekker maar heel apart smaakje. Denk de rye.. hele lange zeer pittige afdronk

proefflesje van Stefan gekregen
Inoffensive rye. Tasted clean and definitely left a thicker grain taste and feeling in the mouth. Smelled sweet and was easy drinking

Splendid nose of vanilla, toasted marshmallow, leather, fresh hay, and pipe tobacco. No ethanol to speak of; easy and really enjoyable to huff.

Palate follows the nose closely, but lose the leather and add caraway-seeded rye bread, brown sugar, cinnamon, black pepper, honey, and just a touch of spearmint. Spicy finish is of decent length. Flavors are nice and bold, and integrate well. 

Mouthfeel is on the thinner side, but has some creaminess and is oily enough to coat the mouth. 

A bottom shelf titan with no discernible flaws. Definitely a bourbon drinker's rye as it is on the sweet side, but seriously a BIB Rye of this quality...for $26???! Let's not tell Heaven Hill they could mark this up 50% and it would still be worth it. Automatic re-buy status for me.

Surprising-
Nose: Maple syrup, toasted marshmallow 
Palate: spice, a little heat & Oak 
Finish: moderate with a warming note
Smooth rye and you can’t go to wrong bottles in bond!
Spicy and fruity, not very complex

Rittenhouse rye is my favorite rye right now.   I have had Sazerac, Dickel, Bulleit, Knob Creek, Old Forester, Old Overholt, and Redemption.   I have not had Lott 40 or Pikesville yet.  I have heard these are great.  That will be for another day.  Rittenhouse Rye is a bottled in bond that is 100 proof.  This one is an amazing value as it is usually about 20-30 bucks most places.  The color is a copper color.  The aroma is a light spiciness with caramel and vanilla.  The palate is a rush of spice with brown sugar and vanilla.  It seems very thick and coating on the tongue which I like.  The finish is long with the spice hanging in there and a little sweetness.
Spicy! Very enjoyable also after adding some drops of water

Nose - spicy and home-y, reminds me of fall

Taste - spicy, apple pie, long finish

Better than any other $30 bottle you’ll find out there. Good stuff
Wow, is this flavorful. Spicy, sweet- a great rye whiskey.
Just gets better and better. Neat, rocks, old fashioned, this one does it all. Smooth sweet buttery rich
Comes on strong but finishes pretty clean.
Very Spicy from front to finish, oak flavors and leathery finish.
Great in an old fashion. My guy was a pro!!!

Orange spice on the nose. Palate follows with baking spices and darker fruit leading to a strong bitter bite making it tough to enjoy neat. It does lend well to cocktails but I’d rather have Old Forster Rye for about the same price.

Nose:
Vanilla, cola, sawdust, chocolate 
Palate:
Cinnamon, cherry, vanilla & hint of Carmel 
Finish:
Red fruit & oak

Rich honey color. Nose has hints of cherry cola, cinnamon and freshly baked bread. Palate has charred cinnamon sticks, freshly ground nutmeg, toasted rye bread, dill, and hints of vanilla and spearmint. Light mouthfeel with a medium finish, with baking spices and toasted rye. Good bang for the buck, and a solid daily sipper.
Nice rye for the price.  Good heat certainly worth the price.

It's the Dr. Pepper of the rye world!
So many flavors going on to its advantage. it's perfection....and you can't beat the price.

Oh!! Almost forgot... When i bought it. The first pour was a bit medicinal and astringent. The second half of the bottle is better because it had some time to open up and breath. Let it sit in the cupboard half gone for a week. You will thank me.
Strong. As DB says, “it’s a little angry.”
Tasty but it’s a little sharp for a first drink.
Vanilla and a little rye spice
One of the best deals out there. Complex, fruity, a little floral and has a nice sweetness. Not a huge rye spice but really easy drinking
Very pleasant. Sweet notes and lots of fruit and complexity.

Tried in a bar in a rocks glass in Philly.

Nose has some vanilla, and nice rye spice.

The palate is sweet with leather, some rye spice and some nice oakyness.

The finish is nice and on the short side if long. It drys the tongue a little.

I like it.
Feels like pop rocks. An easy sipper
Sweet smell with a great warmth on the tongue and a pleasant aftertaste

Nice combination of spice, fruit and sweetness.  I'm learning about Rye and like this one.  BiB helps, on the rocks for me. 

Someone commented a while back, "The Dr. Pepper of rye whiskey" I would agree.

I'll purchase again
Has a licorice flavor on the front
Nice rye! Spicy in front and a little sweet when the ice melt opens it up.
Pretty spicy on the front, then mellows to a lingering sweetness and floral finish
4.5. Best rye for the price. Great neat and makes a great cocktail as well.

Distinct from other rye offerings with its focus on core rye bread and spice character, Rittenhouse Rye opens with rye bread, cinnamon, caraway, clove, nutmeg, cherries, dark maple, and black tea in the nose. Here, caraway steals the show, both for its prominence and its distinctiveness among the notes typical of other ryes. The palate reveals more citrus character, biting rye spice, baked apples, pumpernickel, black tea, orange rind, black soda, and then dries neatly into a drawn out finish which introduces at last menthol to its layered presentation of rye spice character. Warming, with a powerful spice character.
CHERRY. CHERRY. COLA. SPICY. Pepper. vanilla. Yellow cake. Cinnamon. Clove.
Spicy! Can taste the maple finish

NOSE: I’m getting Bourbon but with mint on top. Lack of harsh notes is refreshing.

PALATE: Continues from the nose, it ends with a mint chocolate profile that calls for more!

OVERALL: One of the best US whiskeys at the price no doubt! Fresh and balanced.

Nose: Sugar, vanilla, nutmeg, clove, cinnamon.  Oak.  Citrus oil.  Black tea.  Dill.  Black pepper.  Menthol.

Palate: Sugar, vanilla, clove, nutmeg.  Black tea, dill.  Oak.  White pepper.  Menthol.  Almost a creamy thing going on.  Citrus on the finish.
Nice warm rye. Smokey upfront with burnt marshmallow on the back of the tongue.

Best rye of the four I’ve had yet, and not just the best of but also far better than the others. Spicy, fruity (but not in an overly sweet way), hot...this is delicious. Definitely a bottle I’m keeping on hand.
Lots of spiced type flavor backed by a high proof kick

Nose: Fruit, vanilla, brown sugar/toffee, oak.  Rye spice - star anise, cardamom, clove, dill.  Slightly buttery.  Slight citrus note.  Cereal grain.  Black pepper.

Palate: Vanilla, oak, tannin, sugar.  Rye spice shows up - star anise, clove, subtle dill.  Paprika.  Fruit.  Eucalyptus.  Raw flour, cereal grain, graham cracker.  Citrus.  White pepper.
Lots of notes of cherry, peaches, and other stone fruits on the nose.  Has the hallmark rye spiciness, but balanced with the fruit notes.  Very good rye for the price and my go to house rye.
Strong, interesting tasting .  Chewed in the inside of the lip with your tongue.  Very strong.  Not a big fan.
Smooth sipping liquor. Nice on the tongue and lingers pleasantly.
Bar staple for manhattans. Try it neat with a splash of Eagle Rare for a real treat.
Part of our tour/tasting on 30 Dec 19 at Heaven Hill. Also tasted EC and Larceny

A crisp golden color. Sweet nose with honey and spice, not too harsh. Palate has initial spiciness with some sweet and smoky undertones, surprisingly smooth for a 100 proof rye. Finish is long and warm. A classic rye whiskey made even better by the cheaper price.
Deep copper color. Peaches, grain and cinnamon on the nose. Hits the palate with more stonefruit and a peppery undertone - less rye spice than one might expect. Short finish incorporates some tannin.
Gearing this for mixed drinks. It is not in my wheelhouse like some other rye product.

This is impressive. I was not expecting this at all at this price point. I’m not an expert, only really tried five or six rye. I would take this over the Woodford, Overholt, bulleit, high west off the top of my head. smooth sweet and you still know it’s rye. Will get a bottle to try it in my favorite mixes to see if it should replace the old standard.
Finally trying it. Definitely the best rye I’ve had. Not as in your face spicy.  Lingering on the pallet
grain spice and light vanilla on the nose. Raisins, leather and very spicy on the palate.

This is a DAMN good bang for buck proposition. There are better ryes out there but you’re gonna have to spend a fair bit more than the $25 this asks. You definitely get those anise and dill notes. Makes a damn fine Manhattan as common wisdom says.
Well balanced with a slight kick and slow burn. I’ll be coming back to this for cocktails and sipping.
Heavy on the spice but that would be a great addition to a Manhattan.

This is a spicy boy! Awesome toasted marshmallow notes on the nose with some very light caramel notes. The taste is insanely spicy with some good sweetness to round it out and an almost eucalyptus finish. The first Rye in my collection is one hell of an addition
One of my favorite ryes of all time

Spicy, full, rich, and sweet are my favorite characteristics of any whisky, but what really surprised me about this one is the low price; bang for the buck. In my opinion, this one  is easily in league with or can beat other rye whiskys in the $30-$40 range.

The nose is a sweet, spicy affair with that same peppery smell that I associate with Canadian whiskeys and seldom get on American ryes. On the palate it is sweet, but not cloyingly so; balanced by rye spiciness: cinnamon and nutmeg. A little hot, but to be expected at 100 proof. Finish is long, spicy, and sweet oak. With water, it becomes lighter and spicier, and more complex. This has to be one of my favorite whiskies, and at the price point is hard to beat.

Following up on my review of Pikesville Straight Rye is this review for its younger cousin, Rittenhouse Bottled-in-Bond Rye. The information I could find for this Heaven Hill offering seems to vary a bit depending on where you look and I couldn’t locate an official Heaven Hill specifications page for it. In any case, feel free to chime in if you are aware of one - this is the best I could find for now. 

Mash Bill: 51% Rye, 37% Corn, 12% Malted Barley
Age: 4 years
ABV: 50%
Price: $19.99 (typically seen for $20-$25)

Nose: Surprisingly soft and mellow. Dusty cherries, malty grains, breakfast cereal. Buttery oiliness. I wish it was socially acceptable to have this for breakfast. 

Palate: Rich, oily mouthfeel with gentle rye spice. Peaches and cherries, vanilla, nutmeg, smokey char, and little bits of flake salt. 

Finish: Medium length. Sweet and fruity, with mild spice, smoke, and amber maple syrup sweetness.

Overall Impressions: Not quite as intense or complex as the Pikesville, but still very good in its own right. I think this bottle has either softened a bit since I first first opened it or I have been drinking too much rye lately. It doesn’t seem nearly as spicy as it used to be so I’m curious how the next bottle I crack open will compare. In any case, this is a remarkable bottle for the price (~$20) and something that will always be in my home bar. It is excellent neat or as a mixer. I highly recommend this take a place on your shelf too!

3.75 ~ 85 ~ Good
Rye spice and warmth.  Strong alcohol kick.  This makes a great shot.

Nose: Peppercorns, savory spices, brown sugar. Sweet smoke?!?

Palate: baking spice, semi-sweet chocolate, candy sweet, marshmallows?

Finish: the whisky falls off a bit on the sharp-ish alcohol finish. Not a lot of follow through. Woody, but not in a great way.
How have I never checked this in? Makes a fantastic old fashioned!
Easy drinking, not a lot of bite to it.  As compared to the tasting notes I'm really only getting a buttery smoothness.  Still, if you're looking for a rye this is a solid choice.

Nose: sourdough bread, rye bread, baking spice, allspice

Taste: Rye bread, sugar, bitters, syrup, mint

Finish: mint

	Thoughts: The mint finish is present after a few sips and is pleasant. Staple Rye for the household

Outstanding value, in a whiskey world where it can be very hard to find.
Nose is very soft but generous with dark cherry dominating, hints of butterscotch, rye notes, and a whiff of ethanol. The mouthfeel follows through on the nose, very soft, with rounded full edges. On entry cherry and baked/browned soft apple fruit gives way ever so easily to very well balanced rye spice that blends nicely with notes of dark chocolate. The rye spice moves from back to front, tickling even the lips. The finish, although a bit abrupt/short, fades nicely into cocoa and barrel notes. While not an aggressive, punchy rye, overall a well balanced, soft, delicious pour that delivers just enough rye spice to keep most rye fans happy. Not a single note in this pour could be labeled as unpleasant.

Plastic screw top, unassuming price of $25.  Quick legs, medium amber... decent nose with something of a Buffalo Trace funk.  It’s lively with sour mash, mint and oak.  Smells like May in Kentucky...

Initial tingle on the tongue, then cherries, brown sugar, mint, rye bread.  Still some noticeable sourness on the otherwise short finish.

This brings me to price point.  This is not an uncut, unfiltered party in your mouth.  It is, however, a decent sipping bourbon.  I miss the thick, sweet flavors of say Knob Creek but would take this over Buffalo Trace at the price point.  Not one I lust over or would likely buy again but nothing to regret either. 

Random update - paired with a rice krispy treat this was absolute heaven.  You know, for those of you who are into that sort of thing...

In the realm of eyes, this is easily the best I've had to date. Getting all of the chocolate, orangey full flavor on the palate, and then the spicy, earthy notes on the finish. I put a single cube in there to open it up but will try the next one neat for comparison.
Sweet on the nose and palate with a nice, smooth finish that slowly warms to a lingering peppery note
Honey, caramelized apples, some spice and a pinch of smoke
Always a winner. Great for Manhattans and other cocktails, good sipper, easy to find.
BIB Rye. Sweet scent, sweet sip, 100 proof burn.
Definite fruitiness and sweetness with little bite but an easy drinker.
Not a Rye person! I must say this is quite amazing for the notes I’ve tasted. Tinge of spice upfront then mellows to a sugary vanilla balanced elixir.

Smells like rye, but aroma is pretty faint. I notice the body more than the flavor, super thick and oily, spreads into a great tail. Rye and pepper spice flavors just sit and linger, and there's none of that soapy flavor I sometimes get from ryes. Magnificent.
Spicy but very smooth. Excellent in a Sazerac.
A little hot and comes on strong quick. After a few sips you adjust. Damn good though. Really good over some ice
Sweet smell of caramel. Lot of fruity flavors but the 100 proof does give it a little heat. Does not linger on the palate. With a lower mash rate it is very bourbon-esque. I liked it a lot.

Neat.  A little heat on the nose on a fresh bottle.  Base fruity notes.  Reminds me of fruit cocktail, syrupy peaches, pears, a hint of banana, slight mint and musty barrel.  Lots of pretty rye flavors.  Caramel, Those fruity notes from the nose, stick around, plus some oak, char, allspice, rye grass, hint of vanilla.  Each sip seems to bring something new.  The finish has some caramel sweetness, cinnamon, oak tannins, and some building burn.  The alcohol and medium light mouthfeel and the finish keep it from being cloying.

Overall a very nice drink, especially for the price and readily available.  Great place to start if you want to see if rye is for you, as it is a 'barely legal' rye at 51%

Big fan of Pikesville so eager to try this younger sibling. Poured neat, nice color and coating of my rocks glass. Nose has baking spices and smoky wood with some floral aspects. Cinnamon and rye round it out. Palate is bold spice and sweet wood with the rye taking on some fruity notes like a cognac. Graham cracker and cinnamon in the background add body. Finish is drying wood and char with the baking and cinnamon spice fading slowly. This is very tasty rye. Drinks more like a high rye bourbon to be honest. At $28 paid offers a strong value as well........88/100.........No slight to Ritt but Pikesville is on another level with the depth, maturity of flavors, vibrancy and overall experience. Ran them side by side and its clear. Worth the extra $$ imo..........if you are a fan of Rittenhouse than you will love Pikesville. Both are top notch ryes

Nose:  sweet, maple syrup, mild oak, mild spice
Palate:  lots of rye spice, honey and maple sweetness, oak spice
Finish: medium to long, oak, honey/maple sweetness, mild spice

A really good rye, especially for the price.

Color: dark copper.

Aroma: pepper spice hits hard.

Taste: the spice carries over and is joined by baked goods, gingerbread, and cinnamon.

Finish: hot and medium in duration.
It’s light and drinkable but not exceptional.  For the price, it’s not bad.  Would be good for contrast in a rye tasting.

I have has this rye in my bar right now and it makes me mad but in a good way. I really, really like it probably more than the Bulleit Rye which I have enjoyed for years and has now been replaced. This rye has a great full flavor and like WhiskeyFunatic said it tastes like a "bourbon but with a heavy rye spice kick" and he is correct. This makes a great Rye Old-fashioned and Manhattan. As long as my local store carries it and the price does not go up to much then I will continue to drink this and keep it in my bar.

Nose - licorice, eucalyptus, minty honey, allspice, clove, and other baking spices, caramel, vanilla, moderate/high ethanol burn. 

Taste - eucalyptus, licorice, baking spices, spicy rye (but not too prickly), spearmint, caramel, vanilla, dark cherry, moderate alcohol burn, finishing reasonably long with lingering sweet eucalyptus flavor.

Really solid rye and an extremely good value at less than $30 a bottle.

Seemingly a typical rye whiskey profile, baking spices and a juicy fruit gum aroma with a palate that reminds me of mint and hints of dill. Hits the palate sweet and hot, with oak, vanilla and a slow burn. It’s a good baseline for a rye, would definitely keep it around for cocktails and such.
great middle of the road rye

I got a lot of the rye spice in this but not a whole lot of the rye flavor. It is good but I think it is priced right also. Probably not something I would reach for often when I want something special but I wouldn’t feel bad finishing the bottle either. Overall a good purchase but nothing stands out to me on this!

Nose- cinnamon, caramel, spice

Palate- caramel, spicy, not as sweet on the palate

Finish- spicy, minty, and a small hint of wintergreen, sweeter on the finish than the palate.
Solid rye that makes a very nice cocktail.

Deep, spicy, earthy.

I bought this to make Manhattans and other whiskey cocktails. Previously, I used Bulleit Rye. I didn't care for it neat, but it was a solid mixer. Then, my family gifted me a bottle of Axe and the Oak Colorado Incline Rye. It was very floral when drank neat, but disappeared in a Manhattan. 
This, though, holds up neat and in a cocktail. The Rittenhouse is spicier and hotter like cinnamon. There's some good heat on the tongue and back of the throat. I like it alot. In a Manhattan, it holds its own with my preferred vermouth Carpano Antica. The higher ABV (50%) keeps it from disappearing when mixed. I really enjoy that bit of earthiness it adds to my drink on the finish. 

Overall, it's a solid rye for your cocktail bar.
There's no messing around here, Rittenhouse gets straight to the rye spice which is complemented with the slightly higher ABV. Notes of almond and clove and value for money all over the place.
Can't go wrong with this rye.
Good salted caramel, herbal, and rye bread flavor, but the nose is pretty lackluster, makes a 4-star whiskey into a 3.5 IMO. Despite that it makes a great old fashioned.

I'm embarking on the seven seas of rye. I am always keen to expand my experience and this is where I am.

It's a good place.

The nose. Inviting. Raisins. Oranges. A touch of spice sweet end. Typical caramel and cocoa. The taste... Chewable. Pine perhaps, just a hint. I like the oak level. 

Not a huge finish but pleasantly sweet..warm.

Fine vfm. Comfortable and glugs like a champ.
Rustic and spicy. So good, I got another bottle.

Light copper in color. Lots of oak in the Aroma and more wood notes than I remember.  Rather light Aroma overall.  Does open up with some baking spice and notably cinnamon.  Not a great deal of sweetness in aroma or flavor.  On the palate there is much more heat than other recent 100 proof items I've had.  Couple drops of water brought out more pepper and Rye spice while muting the alcohol heat.
I typically infuse my Rittenhouse with roasted peanuts and love it in that way. I will continue to enjoy in that fashion vs drinking in its original form.
Great for Manhattan's if you don't like them sweet

Color: surprising nice copper/gold.  The bottle doesn't do the color justice.  3.75 on the color scale

Legs: slow forming evenly spaced and slow running down the sides.  3.5

Nose: spicy sweet, low hints of the oak/Carmel and more pronounced clove or black pepper, hint of mint. 4.0

First taste: ultra smooth, perfect viscosity, not a lot of burn on the tongue for a 100 proofer (BiB) 4.0

Taste: really nice balance of spice and traditional rye notes with enough sweetness to take most of the harshness of a rye away.  4.25

Finish: Again, pleasantly surprised by it's easy going nature, minimal burn and consistency from nose through finish. 4.25

Overall: this is a steal of a bottle at $27.  I'm adding this to my best under $50 list and will be on the lookout for more product out of this brand.  Going to go 4.0 overall with a price/value score of 4.5.
Exactly what I want from a rye. Cheap, heavy proof, and spicy.

Very aromatic nose. Cherry and vanilla on the nose for me. Maybe some brown sugar. Rye notes for sure and some perfume on the nose. Nosing too deeply definitely presents some alcohol burn. To taste, sweet at the start but definitely rye forward. Black pepper mid palate and spice. Some alcohol burn on the taste, but it’s minimal for this proof. Surprisingly getting a note of... corn (?)... on the finish this tasting. Amazing value for a rye.
I'm really impressed with this for the price
I look forward to having one or 2 !!! The RYE is SPICY HOT !!

This is decent. Good for the price point. The mash bill seems to be part bourbon and part rye. Not much on the nose. It has a bittersweet palate on the front with a long spicy finish. Great to have on hand for cocktails but decent enough to drink neat.

I'm going to level with you, this thing is straight cinnamon, albeit a good, dry cinnamon. 

Yes, there are notes of black pepper, spicy fruit peel, and even a little char. But to call this anything other than a straight up cinnamon bomb would be underselling exactly how Cinnamon-y this thing really is. 

It's too cinnamon forward for me personally, but I'll bet it would make a hell of a mixer, and it's a considerable upgrade from Fireball. 

I did pour this into a glass of Coke Zero with ice, and as much as the cinnamon is tempered by the cola, it still is overpowering everything in its path. If you like cinnamon this is a very good budget rye that I would recommend, just understand that it is going to be the dominant factor in any mix you put it in.

First real try at a Rye. 
Potent, sweet, bitter finish.
For the price, surprisingly enjoyable and tasty. Has strong spice notes, but finishes pretty smooth.

Nez : Alcool très présent, grain, fleuri, bois et érable ?
Bouche : bouquet d épices, fraîcheur, plantes, sirop
(Il me fait penser plus à une liqueur de plante qu'à un whisky)
Nez +5/10min aeration : arômes sublimée, bois (erable?) Épices et plantes très présentes
Bouche: arômes de liqueurs aux herbes

Rye spice and cherry on the nose. Palate is rich and oily and a little sweet for a Rye, but it’s well balanced with the spiciness you’d expect. Excellent Rye for the price. This has earned a place in my bar.

Nose is buttery rye spice, candy sugar, oak, and cherry.

Taste is cereal, rye spice, marshmallow, and must.

Finish is long and warning.
Great Rye, especially for someone new to Ryes.  Smooth for a BIB with some very nice spice notes. Easily had neat or on the rocks. I recommend this especially for the price.
This stuff is great if a bit simple

Nose is simple and light ethenal. However, the taste is surprisingly interesting and peppery. Some sweetness with the pepper in the finish. What a fantastic value rye! 2nd visit with some water opens and brightens the whole whisky.

Strong flavor. Good burn in the finish. Hint of sweetness at the start with a very sweet finish.

Great for a 20 bottle!
